content: The Air Force plays a role in managing the Civil Air Patrol as a civilian auxiliary of the Air Force. The Civil Air Patrol, as a federally chartered corporation and volunteer civilian auxiliary of the Air Force, is administered by the Chief of Staff of the Air Force under the direction of the Secretary of the Air Force. The Civil Air Patrol, a volunteer civilian auxiliary of the Air Force, is administered by the Chief of Staff of the Air Force under the direction of the Secretary of the Air Force. The organization shall have organizational elements approved by the Secretary of the Air Force. The Secretary appoints a National Board of Directors composed of general officers of the Air Force, including the Air Force Reserve and Air National Guard. The National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol is appointed and composed of general officers of the Air Force, senior civilian employees of the Department of the Air Force, and members from the volunteer Civil Air Patrol membership. The chairman of the Board is the senior active duty Air Force officer, and members appointed from the Civil Air Patrol may not exceed a minority of the Board. The National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol is appointed and composed of general officers of the Air Force, senior civilian employees of the Department of the Air Force, and members from the volunteer Civil Air Patrol membership. The chairman of the Board is the senior active duty Air Force officer. The Board appoints a National Commander, Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General, who report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the Board. The Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General of the Civil Air Patrol report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the National Board of Directors. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign officers, enlisted members, and civilian employees to serve at the national headquarters of the Civil Air Patrol. The appointment or assignment of members is not restricted by any law or regulation. The appointment or assignment of members of the armed forces or civilian employees to management positions in the Civil Air Patrol is not restricted by any law or regulation. Officers or enlisted members of the Air Force serving in these positions will not receive additional compensation beyond their regular military pay. The Civil Air Patrol management positions do not receive extra compensation beyond regular military pay. The Executive Director and National Board of Directors can utilize CAP employees and volunteers as needed for administration and noncombat mission support. The Executive Director and National Board of Directors of the Civil Air Patrol can utilize employees and volunteers as necessary to administer the organization and support noncombat missions.
